results.title: The Quiet war: Vietnam
results.brief_description: An account of the guerilla fighting in South Vietnam and its effect on the lives of the people. The division of Vietnam, the North to the Communists, the South to the Vietnamese, is seen through the eyes of a farming family. They are accustomed to the “quiet war” waged by the Viet Cong guerillas and the South Vietnam Government headed by President Ngo Dinh Diem. In a country of steaming jungles infested with guerillas, constant vigilance is necessary, only armed patrols venturing out at night. The safest place is by the river which forms the border, in the international control area. The Seven Year Old Republic is butressed by the free world to stem the flow of Communist domination in South-east Asia. (please note synopsis written 1964)

results.title: The Quiet room
results.creator_credit: Smile Productions, Vertigo Productions, Fandango, Marvel Movies, SBS Independent, Domenico Procacci and Rolf De Heer
results.brief_description: A seven-year-old girl’s perception of adulthood is portrayed through the marriage breakdown of her parents. Withdrawing into silence as a protest and protection against her parents’ constant fighting, the nameless girl reveals her thoughts through an internal monologue which mixes childishness and vulnerability with emotional sophistication and strength. Her only refuge is her blue-walled room, an exaggerated fantasyland of goldfish, Barbie dolls and toys, where she can remember happier days. de Heer’s acute insights into the young girl’s mentality and speech patterns through his innovative use of sound and silence is combined with a highly stylised mise-en-scene, to convey the hermetic insularity of her childhood world. Like ‘Bad Boy Bubby’, ‘The Quiet Room’ explores the dysfunctional behaviour of parents and the lasting effect it has on their children. Cast includes: Celine O’Leary, Paul Blackwell, Chole Ferguson and Phoebe Ferguson.

results.title: The Quiet racket
results.creator_credit: Guy Glover, ONF | NFB and Gerald Potterton
results.brief_description: An amusing tale of a man who feels the common urge to escape the city’s noise for a weekend of quiet in the hills beyond. Made without words, but with a variety of other sounds, urban and rural, this film tracks our hero to his haven of non-peace. He finds the countryside not as unspoiled and uncrowded as the poets proclaim, nor is the ‘bosom of nature’ entirely without rocks.

results.title: The Quiet man (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Merian C. Cooper, Republic, Argosy and John Ford
results.brief_description: John Wayne plays Sean Thornton, an American prizefighter who swears off boxing for good after accidentally killing an opponent in the ring. Returning to the Irish town of his birth, he discovers renewed interest in life when he falls in love with Mary Kate Donaher (Maureen O’Hara). He also finds a constant temptation to fight her brother, the town bully, but resists until their wedding day … Nominated for seven Oscars and winner of two for director and cinematograpy.

results.title: The Quiet man
results.creator_credit: Republic Pictures Corporation and John Ford
results.brief_description: Set in Ireland in the 1820s, this is the story of Irish-born American Sean Thornton (John Wayne) who, after a long and profitable career as a boxer, returns home to settle down and forget a tragic accident in the boxing ring which killed his opponent. Sean buys back his ancestral home, Thornton Cottage, much to the disgust of the neighbouring squire, Red Will Danaher (Victor McLagen). To further complicate matters, Sean has fallen in love with Red Will’s sister, Mary Kate (Maureen O’Hara). Sean must battle against all manner of Irish blarney to get the hand of the girl he loves. This amusing romantic comedy was a change of pace for John Wayne (and John Ford) at the time, although the movie is usually remembered for the fight scene between the characters of O’Hara and Wayne which culminates in him dragging her across a field followed by the entire village.

results.title: The Quiet Earth
results.creator_credit: Skouras Pictures, Sam Pillsbury, Don Reynolds and Geoff Murphy
results.brief_description: Bruno Lawrence plays a scientist who wakes up one morning to find that an experiment has gone dreadfully wrong and all living things seem to have disappeared from the planet. He searches for other living humans trying to fight off approaching madness and despair. He eventually meets up with two other survivors but as they realise the consequences of the science experiment on the Universe, their relationships fall apart. A haunting and provocative science-fiction film. Based on the novel by Craig Harrison.

results.title: The Quiet American (2001)
results.creator_credit: Intermedia, Mirage Enterprises, IMF (DE), William Horberg, Steffan Ahrenberg and Phil Noyce
results.brief_description: Thomas Fowler (Michael Caine) is an embittered British Journalist working in Vietnam (then Indochina), covering the political situation. A man known for his professional objectivity and honesty, Fowler’s personal life is a fiasco. Involved with a local woman, Phuong (Do Thi Hai Yen), whom he loves, Fowler is married to a strictly religious woman back in England who refuses to divorce him. Into their lives steps an enigmatic American man (Brendan Fraser). The American man falls for Phuong, and asks only that Phuong be given the opportunity to choose between the men and (like Indochina), resolve her destiny. In danger of losing Phuong to the American, Fowler is drawn into a suspicious and venomous state, convinced that the American is supplying explosives to non-Communist troops. “The Quiet American” leaves the more contentious political elements of Graham Greene’s novel to languish in favour of highlighting the personal grief of a middle-aged man in crisis. This version directed by Phillip Noyce is a remake of the 1958 film directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz. Filmed on location in Vietnam and Fox Studios, Sydney.

results.title: The Quiet American
results.creator_credit: Figaro Films and Joseph L Mankiewicz
results.brief_description: Thomas Fowler (Michael Redgrave) is an embittered British journalist working in Vietnam (then Indochina), covering the political situation. A man known for his professional objectivity and honesty, Fowler’s personal life is a fiasco. Involved with a local woman, Phuong, whom he loves, Fowler is married to a strictly religious woman back in England who refuses to divorce him. Into their lives steps an enigmatic American man who hopes to rally the people of Indochina to become a third force and challenge the factions that seek to over-determine their lives. The American man falls for Phuong, and asks only that Phuong be given the opportunity to choose between the men and (like Indochina), resolve her destiny. In danger of losing Phuong to the American, Fowler is drawn into a suspicious and venomous state, convinced that the American is supplying explosives to non-Communist troops. “The Quiet American” leaves the more contentious political elements of Graham Greene’s novel to languish in favour of highlighting the personal grief of a middle-aged man in crisis. Redgrave is impressive as Fowler, whose voice-over narration relays comprehension of his fate, and his disastrous attempt to fight it. Remade in 2002 by Phillip Noyce.
